segments.text: Well, one of the most interesting things about perception is a statement by Dr. Rainey, who was a Special Assistant for Science in the Assistant Secretary's office, plus the fact is now Chief Scientist for Office of Naval Research, denies that I or anybody else ever attempted to consolidate the oceanographic program in Washington, and we

That is the biggest crock I ever saw because we tried to, we knocked heads together during Tex Treadwell's time to set up the Maury Center and put the research and development physically at the Naval Research Laboratory and stuck it in some buildings.
And then I guess things sort of went downhill, but we never got it completely done.
Because if that had been done, we'd have never had any reason to even look outside of Washington.
Because anybody would rather have his own organization in his backyard than to have it, for example, over in a place that is far remote from where he's getting his dollars.
And in fact, we even called it the Maury Center.
We even hired Dr. Hersey from Woods Hole to try to pull it together.
And we never really pulled it together.
And I hope we can do it this time.
Because I think this is our last chance to pull it together.
Exactly what would you like to put all together?
I'd like to put every bit of ocean science together under one single manager in the Navy.
Now, I am not one of those people.
want to take university academic research and put it under single czar.
And when Bill Nuremberg told me this, I said, look, Bill, you're crazy.
You want to come to Ed Snyder, and if I say no, I can't fund you, you don't want to be able to go to anybody else?
I said, you've got the best of both worlds now.
You've got three people you can go to.
You can go to Guy Stever, Ed Snyder, or Bob Abel.
Bob Abel runs the Sea Grant program.
Dr. Stever up until recently ran the National Science Foundation, and I theoretically ran, and I always use the word theoretically because in the Navy you're never sure who runs what.
the Navy's effort.
If you put it under one individual, scientists don't like to knock at one door and not have another door to go to.

And I think that people who argue that there are 21 agencies plus in oceanography don't know what they're talking about in university research because right today it's probably the best coordinated program in the federal bureaucracy.
In fact, it may even be too well coordinated.
It's coordinated basically through my being double-hatted to the National Science Foundation and to Dr. Hughes

where the two of us look at both programs together, and then Bob Abel, who used to be the executive secretary of the ICO for whom we used to work together, having such an interrelationship that I seriously doubt if you'd want to really take science and coordinate it any better.
Science, I'm talking about, basic science.
Now, the Navy's definition of ocean science is weird compared to yours because the Navy's runs even into operational money.
It just happens to divide its program into science, engineering, operations, and prediction.
But when I have to be careful of my words,
nomenclature, because to use science as university, to the Navy that's called basic research 6.1, and to somebody else it's called.
But we're talking about the work done in universities.
And my position has been, since I've been involved in this program and still is,
that the basic research being done in the universities and the academic world and nonprofit organizations of this country in oceanography can best be done there.

And I maintain a very small capability to do that internally within the Navy because I think the rewards and the incentives in the academic community are greater physically in the university or the nonprofit than they are within a Navy industrial type laboratory, even though we have basic research, as we call it, done in our laboratories.
The reason that I'm trying to consolidate that group with the people working on the in-house group is to ensure that the people in the academic world have some feel for what the Navy's needs are.
The Navy still can provide, even though it doesn't look like it's providing much dollars, it still has almost 400 ships.
It almost, I think, something over 100 at sea every day.

over a hundred and thousand people at sea every day, if I can somehow use some of this to help us solve our problems, because in addition to the great scientists, the problem in oceanography is the lack of capability for collecting information, and I'm trying to use the operational Navy to collect information.
I'm building a, I've abolished the weather service, I've changed its name, I've physically taken it and put it at this center down in Mississippi to

Because the other end of those people are not dollars, but they're 1,600 and some enlisted men and officers riding around in aircraft carriers on admiral staffs and at fleet weather centrals whose only job is to predict the environment and to forecast it, taking the information.
And if I can use those and somehow escalate their capability along with the scientific community, I'd sort of use them as a negative feedback loop.
They're out there where the user is.
The difference between the Navy...
for example, in the foundation, and I'm also double-hatted at NOAA, is the Navy is a user of its own science.
The National Science Foundation just does science for science sake.
And I'm not being critical.
and perhaps some people say science for science sake, but I mean science in order to be able to move forward and understanding.
But they're not going to use the science themselves.
The rest of the country will probably use it or somebody else.
NOAA would like to say, and they always tell me that they are producing oceanography for a reason.
They are, but the reason is not for themselves.
They don't depend on oceanography in any sense as a user.
They collect information, bring it together, and give it to other people to use it.
The Navy
theoretically uses everything it does.

I think an interesting thing is the Navy not only uses what it does, but the Navy uses what the Foundation does, and the Navy uses what NOAA does, because WODC, the World Oceanographic Data Center, and the National Oceanographic Instrument Center were in fact owned by the Navy during the time that I was physically in the Washington Arena.
Didn't go back, didn't go out of the Navy until I think 1971 when Nixon reorganized and formed NOAA.
I think the big critical things coming up now in the future
in oceanography are the so-called engineering and undersea technology in the development cycle because of the oil interest and because of the other thing.
And I think the universities have been significantly
helpful in this area and yet cannot afford to run the kinds of programs that demand huge pieces of systems and equipment.
And yet I think perhaps Woods Hole, and believe it or not, even Texas A&M, now with their advent of, I believe, putting the Perry Cub Marine and getting engineering-wise, are probably
the two most advanced in what I call engineering.
Scripps would get very upset in Miami and all the rest of them, and they would say, well, putting out buoys in engineering.
That's not what I mean.

I mean undersea technology, the ability to operate at any depth, at any time, at any place in the world's ocean, which is my objective, my military mission, and I never will achieve it as long as I live or my son lives, but I'd sure give it a healthy college try.
And that's costly because that demands huge systems, long development times, and large expenditures of money, even more so than Oceania.
Now, in 1953, let's say, when you arrived and looked over the bureaucratic organization in Washington, when were you first struck that consolidation had to take place?
I'm being unfair.
You seem to be a consolidator all along because the assistant secretary asks you, what would you do?
And you say, I would consolidate or I would abolish it.
Do you usually look at problems this way?
Yes, I guess I do.
I guess I have a weakness of always wanting to get a critical mass.
I guess my disgust with science, my disgust with anything I've ever done is that to watch various people doing little bits and pieces and realize that
that it lacks a critical mass.
And you don't necessarily have to consolidate to get a critical mass.
But you can't run a three-man post office department in science or engineering and everybody tries to do it.
It takes a certain amount of manpower.
And this doesn't mean they all have to work for one boss.
And this doesn't mean they all have to be under one roof.
But it means they all have to be pulling together.
And it's very difficult to get people pulling together unless you physically put them together or you let them meet all the time.
And in the academic world, I think we've been very fortunate, certainly
up until very recently, of being able to get them all working together and meeting together, but not necessarily working together geographically.
But they're being forced to work together in large sea experiments geographically because nobody can any longer afford to do his own experiments.
In a sense, the system is driving it that way.
And I look at that as the word critical mass.
And maybe that's because of my nuclear physics background.
But to me, that means something.
That means it can run on its own.
That means it can survive.
That means it can, in fact, recreate and generate.
It can, in fact, create matter.
Now, that's my layman's view of what I mean by critical mass.
And I'm concerned that in oceanography, we tend to...
to have a lot of little isolated groups.
But I do not think this is a problem in the academic oceanography, but it's certainly now a problem in the engineering side of oceanography.
Terrible.
I have a follow-up question on that I intend to ask later from something you said previously, but you're now like that.
Does it not seem to you that such things as 200-mile limits, international conferences,
In effect, that oceanography has, world oceanography, has become more and more involved in the political realm with the development of third world powers?
Absolutely.
Does that seem to work against your idea of creating critical masses?
Yes, it does, because there are lots of people in the bureaucracy that like to isolate things by how you do them as opposed to specific disciplines.
I think the oceanographic community and the Navy in particular were very remiss not to forecast what was going to happen with the 200-mile limit.
I certainly know that Dr. Wakeman did.
I know we did in the Secretary's office.
We were just basically not listened to.
We really weren't prepared for this.
I think that the...

The interesting part of oceanography, again, which is again unique in the scientific sense, and this speaks to the international sense, is that what happens on the coast of Africa may very well affect what happens on the coast of North America.
Now, you can trap me here and maybe I'm in the wrong realm of current flow and basin flow and theory, but certainly my statement in general is true.
And this basically says that you have to work together.
It doesn't mean you have to do it under the United Nations, under a single organization.
But again, you're going to have to have at least a group of people that have subcritical mass so that when they can survive on their own and at the same time they're
they can gain by working together with someone else.

And this has been our big push in scientific academic oceanography to ensure that the world does not think of these people as exploiters, but rather as people who are trying to explore and lay the basis for their own benefits.
We can't just say, I want to look at what's off my own coast and try to figure out what effect it's going to have on
the atmospheric weather, on where the fish go, where are the minerals, how do we get the best point-to-point transportation.
I think we certainly should have learned in this country by now, we may never have learned it, but you don't move large masses of things by air.
The McNamara philosophy of everything's done by air, it was disproved certainly in Vietnam where still 98% of everything went by sea.
You're moving tremendous tonnages of food, of petroleum products, of machinery, of equipment, and of course in the military also of ammunition.

Now, it is better to move men by air and to move certain other things, but the Flying Tigers World War II bootstrap operation to carry 50 gallons of gas to get five there is not only inefficient, but it's almost impossible in modern technology.
That's an opinion, but I think we're seeing the revival of the importance of marine transportation.

And yet, interestingly enough, the politics of the merchant marine have been so sticky that everybody who's tried to look at how you bring consolidation together in the federal government has been afraid to tackle it.
And I've been involved in almost every single tackling of it.

consolidation or bringing things together or cutting up the pie that's been, it doesn't mean I'm running it, but I've certainly been involved in it as a staff member or as a guy sitting on the outside.

Oceanography, of course, has been escalated to the White House, if you want to look at it that way, from the Humphrey era when he was chairman of what we used to call the Wet Space Committee, which is what the Marine Sciences Council.
Another thing that, well, I guess that's it.
Politics play a very important part in oceanography, and I guess I didn't realize that initially, because I'd never been thrown into politics until I got into oceanography.
You can see why I get concerned.
The world is negative.
They'll cut you when you don't look at it.
Well, I have a follow-up now on this idea of international cooperation.

How do you as a Navy man, for example, feel about what seems to be, because of the need to bring a critical mass together, to use your word, they're growing international cooperation from the ships at sea.
The Soviet Union, the Norwegians, the Americans have done more than just a few joint ventures, including Moho, for example.
I don't have any heartburn with that.
I guess perhaps many people do.
But if you go back and analyze the history of going to sea in general, seamen generally fought as gentlemen and generally hated to fight.
They were all after you, Alphonse, and they'd all stand off while two people battled it out.
And I think the reason for that, again, is the environment.
The environment was so destructive and so overwhelming that the respect for the environment was so great that people fought, if you will, gentlemanly wars.
The thing that destroyed the

The attempted to destroy gentlemanly wars were pirating back many, many hundreds of years ago, periodically, and that was finally, I guess the American Navy was the one that wiped that out for the rest of the world.

Then the next thing that began to attempt to destroy the gentleman's agreement, as I call it, of how we all are bound together by the sea rather than by the national flag, was the advent of the submarine, who would stick his periscope up and fire indiscriminately at passenger ships and warships.
That certainly has caused us a lot of problems, and
Yet, on the other hand, that's perhaps maybe even brought us together on occasion.
I think that seamen have historically been more afraid of the sea than they have of the enemy.
Maybe that's an over-exaggeration.
I think they've certainly been willing to sit down.

I think there's another thing that many people don't recognize, and that is that if you are king of Xavier, say, for example, and I bring a ship in, I bring it in because I ask you if I may bring it in.
And you as a gentleman say, well, certainly.
But interestingly enough, I'm really not resident in your country.
You can tell me tomorrow morning at 8 o'clock to get my butt out and I can go.
Whereas you might be reluctant politically to bring in an air group and put it in your backyard or an army tent because that's symbolic.
Whereas the ship is merely tied by lines to your pier and is by law, a warship by law, is still sovereign territory and land
of the country to which it belongs.
So you're taking a piece of America and temporarily tying it up along the Xavier Principality or whatever country you have, and I think that
This is particularly true in science.
Now, when you get into hardware, then you're talking something else.
Then you're talking competition for economic or other reasons which may be different.
And I think you will find the biggest heartburn comes in sharing technology which may destroy you economically or militarily rather than sharing science.
in the ocean.
That's an opinion, but I certainly think that I have the full support of the hierarchy of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Secretariat on fully supporting international science.
There are many people who would not like to do this, but as far as policy is concerned, I have the full support, and I think that's an interesting thing because you wouldn't get that in other fields.
I have another question that leads to about consolidation here.
Would your plans of consolidation or your attempt to...
and probably successful to move to Mississippi been possible without computers?
Absolutely not.
The thing that made a consolidation down there possible are two things, three things.
Good air transportation, good computer tied-in systems, and good communication systems.
In fact, we don't have the best communication system down there.
We've got a Navy communication system, and right now there's a lot better commercial
communication, television, satellite systems for command and control available other than the kind the Navy has.

And I'm looking forward to maybe getting one of those because I think that if you're going to prove to yourself you can run something outside of the center of the bureaucracy where the heartbeat of the bureaucracy is, you've got to be sure you know what it's doing and can use it to justify your thousands of requests that come in from the

bureaucracy all right well uh along that line would it have been possible for for you to think in terms of organization of a bureaucratic institution as bringing the various elements of oceanography together in one building if you had not been in one of the early disciplines or scientists which involve computer work that is nuclear physics i don't really understand that question well uh
The first beginning of organizations in science, I would argue, comes from those nuclear physicists, particularly nuclear... Oh, the Manhattan Project.
Oh, absolutely.
But that was brought together for a different reason, and there were not computers then.
The Navy was working on its first computer with Harvard called the Mark I Brain down at Dahlgren, Virginia, as I remember it, in the late 30s.
The reason they brought the physicists together was just because it was an early discipline.
They needed to get out in some remote location because they were fighting in a sense of what they might find when they developed it.
They were going to
develop it not as a scientific tool, but towards a specific end project.
I mean, everybody knew exactly what they were going to try to do with it.
So they put them together, and of course it only lasted during the war, and the scientific part of it almost fell apart within months after the war was over.
At least I was over there at Los Alamos right after the war.
That doesn't true.
There were great brains, Teller, Oppenheimer, so forth.
But basically the real desire to work together disintegrated at the end of World War II, as I read it.
even though we were trying to work on the hydrogen bomb.

But the real motivation to work together for, if you will, survival against the so-called Axis powers was what I think gave the, not the impetus for the consolidation, but the real reason that let them come together and put everything together.
And of course, there were problems there.
The problems there were mostly military, where if you had a PhD in nuclear physics, you were a buck private, and if you were driving the major, you were probably a top sergeant.
That's another problem.
Well, how do you explain, then, your developing interest in consolidation?
When is it first apparent to you in 63 that the parts of oceanography have got to be consolidated?
Because none of them had enough capability on their own to ever either articulate the need for the importance to the oceans...
the need for the oceans in their business, or worse than that, what it is they wanted to do when they got together.
Because we were doing it through committee work, but it was getting bigger.
And once it got big enough so that it became huge, you just can't sit down with a group of 12 people around a table.
In 1963, I'll bet you by the end of the time Tex Treadwell had trained me, I'll bet you I knew
90% of everybody working in oceanography, or knew of them, and I bet I knew almost that much of what they were doing.
Today, I don't even know what the Navy's doing.
It's gotten so diffuse that I can't really tell you what we're doing in great detail, even within the Navy, much less within the rest of the world.
Now, you can say that's maybe bureaucracy, but I think as the group gets bigger, as the
as the instruments become more complicated, more sophisticated, as the necessity for working together to solve the technical problems.
For example, in oceanography, no longer, in my opinion, can a man take a thesis and take a ship and go to sea and make a significant thesis.

Now, you'll get a thesis and get a Ph.D. that way, but as far as really beginning to solve the problems of what is the ocean like, you're now well beyond a single oceanographer dipping his wick in a single ship.
I mean, we are at the point right now where, to do a job right, we tie a satellite or an aircraft or some other kind of worldwide sensor in with the ground truth of the ship.

And if you start looking at it from that viewpoint and you look at it from a military viewpoint, the military man has long known that one person working independently doesn't accomplish very much except in espionage, but in operations he accomplishes very little.
Perhaps it's the military mind or the experience
when you're working together.
But I don't really mean when I say consolidate to put everything under one individual.
Consolidate to me is to consolidate one's effort, initiative, and raison d'etre, why we're here and what we're trying to do.
I would not go beyond the consolidation I think we have now achieved in the academic world.
I think that's about the optimum.
What sort of opposition did you meet in the beginning?
You mean from 63?

The opposition of the people who call themselves oceanographers but didn't really want to because they had been in another discipline or they were mapmakers or they didn't want to do this or didn't want to do that.
In the Navy, everybody has his own organization, so therefore he doesn't want somebody else to serve him.
If it were sexy or fascinating or necessary, he'd probably do it himself, but he wouldn't want to do it with somebody else.
I think it's probably a relationship of Parkinson's first, second, third, and fourth laws combined together with the Peter Principle
It says that humans, being what we are, will never really attempt to do the ultimate, but to do that which we see can be done most expeditiously.
Now, and how did you handle problems in reorganization?
Did you try to transfer people out?
No.
Try to reason with them?
Try to reason with them.
I never tried at that time to hit people over the head because I wasn't that type of individual, nor did I think we would gain very much.

I think we only transferred one individual, and the reason for that was in trying to set up a new program for surface type of ships, that is, and that's part of oceanography in a sense, in trying to design new hull forms and break through the frontier that we found the individual most competent to do this was sitting up in an air development center, and he was too remotely associated with the people who went to sea and too intimately associated with the people who flew all the time so that
To put him in charge of a new design of ships, he needed to have some kind of tie to the people who had some capability.

I don't think you ever want to bind people to the past, but you certainly would like to link them so that they can come down that tradition and pick from the past what's important and yet reject the old if it isn't important.
You can't be too tied, but you have to be somehow willing to get some support from the past.
or by the past, I mean in this case, the capability.
Many people argue that's not right, that you just go out in the wilderness, you carve out a hunk of desert, and you start from scratch.
Well, they did that at Los Alamos, but that was a wartime situation, and everybody knew what they wanted to achieve, and the question was how to achieve it.
I think in oceanography, we've only had glimpses of what it is we wanted, but we've never been totally able to articulate exactly what we wanted.
And probably until that happens, we'll...
have a difficult time.
Look, can that happen in something as fast-changing as the Navy?
It's happened before.
It only happens once in the, probably in a generation.
We went from sail to steam and it damn near killed everybody.
We went into the submarine Navy and they tried to ignore it.

We went into the battleship Navy and they tried to ignore that in Civil War and then we got so entrenched in the battleship Navy we couldn't get in the air Navy and now we're in the air Navy and so entrenched now we can't see the rest of the Navy and it's interesting.
Well, you look at what you think the Navy will look like 20 X number of years in the future.
you also ask yourself very broad scientific questions.
You ask yourself, what are the fundamental requirements?
Not what requirements are dictated by what you have or what you may have, but what are the fundamental requirements?
And I guess it was very easy for me as an individual who had no knowledge whatsoever to be very fundamental.

You know, my comment, the Navy must have the capability to operate at any time, at any depth, at any point in the world's ocean is a very simple statement, but that generates about $10 billion worth of requirements.
That says you've got to build a submersible that goes down to
That says you've got to have remote control vehicles that can do the same.
And then from that, you say, well, now where can I get from there?
And how important is it?
And where do I put my priorities?
And you suddenly recognize that very little of the ocean is deeper than 20,000 feet.
So why pay 10 times as much for a capability to get that 2%?
Because the day we need it so badly, we'll go to 20,000.
So we'll design our systems around 20,000 foot depth.
So you can say, well, I didn't meet my major objective, but I met, say, 98% of it.
It's always a give and take.
The argument of whether you use, for example, you could say, well, I want all my equipment manned.
I want all my equipment unmanned.
You can use the space argument.
I think we in oceanography and ocean engineering and undersea technology
We've looked at it from three basic ways of doing business.
You do it with a man in the vehicle, you do it remotely from a surface vessel, or you do it in some combination thereof.
So you look at what combinations could you possibly do, and you get the surface ship that can put a pipe type of arrangement, stiff arrangement down on the bottom.
You get the surface ship that can tow a flexible cable in the fish, and then you get the
The vehicle itself, and the vehicle happens to be called a submersible, and they make many kinds of submersibles.

And ideally, and I've been fighting for it for years and never won, I wanted a large submarine, non-combatant, that carried little baby submersibles that could operate below the surface air interface so that you could launch at any time of the day and you could do things in the complete oblivion of a relatively tranquil environment from a surface wave combo.
